presentation.title: What's Actually Agentic?
presentation.subtitle: An Honest Look at Our IT Due Diligence System

theme.style_notes: Minimal, dark mode, generous whitespace, accent colors for emphasis only

slides.title: What's Actually Agentic?
slides.subtitle: An Honest Assessment of Our Architecture
slides.visual: abstract geometric pattern with nodes and connections
slides.notes: Clean title slide, subtle animated background

content.subtext: It's a custom Python application calling the Claude API directly.

slides.title: The Entire Tech Stack
slides.footer: That's it. No frameworks. No vector databases. No RAG pipelines.

slides.title: The Only Truly Agentic Part

content.description: Inside the Claude API call, the model autonomously decides:

slides.highlight: That decision-making loop is genuinely agentic. The model chooses, not a script.

slides.title: 1. Orchestration is Hardcoded
slides.code:
# main.py - this is just a script
domain_agents = [
    (InfrastructureAgent, "Infrastructure"),
    (NetworkAgent, "Network"),
    (CybersecurityAgent, "Cybersecurity"),
    # ... always these 6, in this order
]
slides.callout: No decision about WHICH agents to run. Always the same 6.

comparison.true_agent: Looks at document, decides 'this needs security focus'
comparison.our_system: Runs all 6 agents regardless of content

slides.title: 2. No Inter-Agent Communication

diagram.description: Each writes to store independently. They never talk.

slides.callout: The 'coordinator' just reads output after. It's not orchestrating—it's summarizing.

items.title: No Planning
items.description: Agents don't create plans. The 'plan' is baked into the prompt.

items.title: No Memory
items.description: Every run starts fresh. Doesn't learn from past analyses.

items.title: No Self-Correction
items.description: If an agent makes a mistake, nothing catches it.

slides.title: Honest Capability Assessment
slides.visual: Checkmarks in green, X marks in red/coral

slides.title: What This System Actually Is

definitions.label: Accurate Description
definitions.text: Parallel tool-augmented LLM calls with structured output and post-hoc synthesis

definitions.label: Simple Version
definitions.text: Six specialized prompts running in parallel, each with tools for structured output, followed by a summarization prompt

slides.callout: The 'agentic' part is Claude deciding how to use tools. Everything else is orchestration code.

content.main_point: IT due diligence is a well-defined task
reasons: Fixed output structure (risks, gaps, work items)
content.conclusion: You don't need dynamic planning when the plan is always the same.

slides.title: Where the Real Value Comes From
slides.footer: Not from agents autonomously deciding what to do.

slides.title: What Would Make It More Agentic?
slides.subtitle: (If We Wanted To)

slides.title: A Truly Agentic Architecture

layers.name: PLANNER AGENT
responsibilities: 'This is heavy on security, light on network'
Decides which agents and how deep

layers.name: DYNAMIC EXECUTION
responsibilities: Agents spawned based on planner's decision
Agents can request help from each other
Agents can spawn sub-agents for deep dives

layers.name: CRITIC AGENT
responsibilities: Sends agents back for another pass

slides.footer: But this adds complexity, cost, and latency—may not improve output for a well-defined task.

items.label: What we have
items.value: Smart prompts with tool use, run in parallel, with structured output

items.label: What it actually is
items.value: Scaled prompt engineering with good orchestration

items.label: Is that bad?
items.value: No. It works. The output is good.

slides.title: The Term 'Agent' Is Overloaded
slides.quote: The industry calls any tool-using LLM an 'agent.' That's fine. Just know what you're actually building.
